channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Adopts Law Weakening Supreme Court
item.description: Complaining of an unaccountable judiciary, the far-right governing coalition, despite months of mass protests, voted to strip the court’s power to override “unreasonable” government actions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting on Monday night in Tel Aviv against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the Israeli judicial system.

item.title: Netanyahu Scores Another Victory, but at What Price?
item.description: The Israeli prime minister has pushed through the first part of his judicial overhaul, but in doing so has deepened a rift in Israeli society and propelled the country into an uncertain new era.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, in the Knesset on Monday.

item.title: Russia Strikes Danube Port, Escalating Attacks on Ukraine Grain Routes
item.description: The assault, across the river from Romania, heightened the risk of a more direct confrontation with a NATO member and came on the same day that drones struck buildings in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Andrés R. Martínez, Haley Willis and Tiffany May
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian Armed Forces on Monday showing a grain warehouse in a seaport in the Odesa region that was destroyed by a Russian drone strike.

item.title: What the Collapse of Spain’s Far Right Means Going Forward
item.description: About the only thing clear from Spain’s muddled election results was that Spaniards were turning away from the political extremes.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Supporters of the Spanish far-right Vox party gather outside the party headquarters in Madrid after Spain’s general election on Sunday.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russia Strikes Danube River Port, Escalating Attacks on Ukrainian Agriculture
item.description: A drone attack on a port near Romania signaled that Moscow, after pulling out of a deal enabling Ukraine to ship grain via the Black Sea, is targeting alternate export routes.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Israel Protests: Protests Intensify Despite Offer to Delay Broader Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Israel’s Parliament passed a contentious measure limiting the Supreme Court’s powers. The country’s nationalist right celebrated the law’s passage as just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: China Gym Roof Collapse Claims at Least 11 Lives
item.description: A building contractor improperly stored material on the gym’s roof, official media reported. Most of the victims were children.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: CNS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a middle school gym in Qiqihar, China, early on Monday.

item.title: Fires Strike Corfu and Evia in Greece as Rhodes Continues to Burn
item.description: New blazes broke out on Corfu and Evia as tourists were being flown home.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Wildfires near the village of Asklipieio, on the island of Rhodes, Greece, on Monday.

item.title: Seeking Full Honors, Some Ukrainian Families Wait to Bury Their Dead
item.description: Thousands of families have buried soldiers in cemeteries across Ukraine in “Alleys of Heroes.” But some have held off, awaiting a version of Arlington National Cemetery.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iryna Gubarieva in her son’s bedroom in Kyiv, Ukraine, where an urn on the shelf holds his ashes. Her son, Dmytro Gubariev, a Ukrainian soldier, died defending the city of Mariupol.

item.title: Macron’s Lesson After Riots? France Needs Order ‘at Every Level’
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France had outlined 100 days to move past protests over his pension reform, but rioting set off by a fatal police shooting jolted the country once more.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking to the news media on Monday at La Tontouta International Airport in Noumea, the capital of the French territory of New Caledonia.

item.title: Iranian Mothers Choose Exile for Sake of Their Daughters
item.description: Some have risked their lives to escape to Iraq or other nearby countries, where they have found havens to start over.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:description: Sima Moradbeigi fled Iran with her husband and daughter, with the aid of a human smuggler, after being shot and seriously wounded by state security forces.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Fined for Disobeying Police at Climate Protest
item.description: The climate activist said that trials like hers brought attention to climate change and that she would continue to protest.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The climate activist Greta Thunberg was carried away by police officers during a protest on Monday in Malmo, Sweden.

item.title: End of Nigerian Fuel Subsidy Fuels Crippling Inflation
item.description: In his first two months in office, President Bola Tinubu has ripped the Band-Aid off Nigeria’s ailing economy. Time will tell if it can heal, but for now, Nigerians are feeling the pain.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Alfa, Elian Peltier and Nelson C.J.
item.media:description: A market in Kano, Nigeria, this month. Food prices have risen in part because of the removal of fuel subsidies.

item.title: Indonesia Boat Accident Leaves at Least 15 Dead
item.description: Most passengers traveling on the overcrowded boat survived Monday’s accident off the island of Sulawesi.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Indonesian National Search and Rescue Agency (BASARNAS)/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Rescuers and local residents searching for victims after a boat capsized off the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, on Monday.

item.title: Putin Signs a Harsh New Law Targeting Transgender People in Russia
item.description: The law, part of a broader L.G.B.T.Q. crackdown, includes a ban on transition surgery.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Russian police officers blocking L.G.B.T.Q. protesters in St. Petersburg in 2019.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Mass Protests in Israel
item.description: Also, political uncertainty in Spain and Twitter’s rebranding.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Tel Aviv last night.

item.title: Protests in Israel Intensify After Vote on Judicial Limits
item.description: Outraged opponents of the government’s removal of some of the Supreme Court’s powers blocked roads around the country. Police responded on horseback and with water cannons.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters in Jerusalem on Monday night.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: An important vote on Israel’s political future.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: On Saturday the demonstrations culminated with tens of thousands of people marching up a hill to Jerusalem from the mountains outside the city.

item.title: Russia Destroys Drones Targeting Moscow, and Blames Ukraine
item.description: Two buildings were hit but there were no reports of casualties. Video verified by The New York Times shows smoke and damage to several buildings.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez, Haley Willis and Tiffany May
item.media:description: A damaged building in Moscow on Monday after a drone attack.

item.title: Spain Elections: Results Show No Party With Enough Votes to Govern
item.description: The returns showed no party winning the support needed to govern, leaving the country facing weeks of uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A polling station in Madrid on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A Major Vote in Israel
item.description: Also, Cambodia’s elections, Ukraine’s counteroffensive and Japan’s coal plants.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Israelis protested the judicial overhaul plan outside Parliament yesterday.

item.title: U.S. Confronts Tight but Turbulent Relationship With Israel
item.description: President Biden has cautioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu against pursuing a proposal to rein in Israel’s judiciary, a plan that has deeply divided Israeli society.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel met with President Biden in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel’s Identity Hangs in the Balance Over a Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Lawmakers are set to vote Monday on whether to limit the Supreme Court’s power as one element of a government plan to overhaul judicial authority. It is part of a profound rift over Israel’s nature and future.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Protesting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plan to limit judicial power in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Wildfires on Rhodes, Greece, Force Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: As firefighters fought blazes kindled by tinder-dry conditions, the authorities sent tourists and residents on Rhodes to schools, gyms and boats moored at the port for shelter.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Damage near the beach at Lindos, a resort on the Greek island of Rhodes, on Saturday.

item.title: Weary Soldiers, Unreliable Munitions: Ukraine’s Many Challenges
item.description: A month of reporting by New York Times journalists found the fighting mostly stalemated and Ukraine facing an array of obstacles against a determined foe.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak, Dzvinka Pinchuk, Yurii Shyvala and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: In Iran, It’s Scorching Hot and Water Supplies Are Shrinking
item.description: Water shortages from longtime mismanagement have left people with shrinking options, as temperatures spike and growing poverty makes air-conditioning unaffordable for many.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: A dried-out riverbed in Isfahan, in central Iran, last month.

item.title: Russian Missiles Strike Odesa Cathedral and Apartment Buildings
item.description: Moscow has renewed its attacks on the port city since pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal last week.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: A cathedral damaged in a Russian missile attack on Sunday in Odesa, Ukraine.

item.title: Netanyahu Fitted With Heart Pacemaker as Israel’s Turmoil Intensifies
item.description: Doctors said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was “doing very well” after the unexpected procedure early Sunday, but the news only compounded the chaos over a government plan to limit judicial power.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, shown this spring, was hospitalized early Sunday and got a pacemaker.

item.title: What to Know About Spain’s Election on Sunday
item.description: The national elections could see a far-right party enter the Spanish government for the first time since the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times
item.media:description: This past week in Barcelona, the capital of Spain’s Catalonia region, which has seen a prolonged secessionist conflict.

item.title: Cambodian Election 2023: Hun Sen’s Party Declares Victory
item.description: The party of Hun Sen, who has been prime minister for nearly four decades, declared victory on Sunday in parliamentary elections that set the stage for his son to rule the country.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cambodia’s prime minister, Hun Sen, casting his vote on Sunday in Kandal Province. Mr. Hun Sen has announced that at some point after the election he will hand over the position to his eldest son.

item.title: Nova Scotia Flooding: At Least Four Remain Missing After Extreme Rain
item.description: Parts of the province recorded its heaviest rainfall since 1971. The flooding forced hundreds to evacuate, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Carballo
item.media:credit: Nigel Gloade/Millbrook First Nations, via Reuters
item.media:description: Water flowing on Sunday through a washed-out culvert in Truro, Nova Scotia, on a rail line leading to the Port of Halifax.

item.title: Richard Barancik, Last of the World War II Monuments Men, Dies at 98
item.description: He played a role in the celebrated Allied operation to preserve European artworks and cultural treasures stolen by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: How the Hunt for a Lioness Near Berlin Turned Into a Wild Boar Chase
item.description: The heavily armed search that upended the southern edge of the German capital met an anti-climactic end — and left some scratching their heads: “A wild boar doesn’t really look like a lion.”
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Police officers searching for a suspected loose lioness in Kleinmachnow, on the outskirts of Berlin, on Friday.

item.title: Wildfires Imperil Greek Isle of Rhodes, Forcing Big Relocation
item.description: Greek Coast Guard vessels were dispatched to rescue visitors and residents trapped in threatened seaside villages on the large island, a leading tourist destination. Some fled in their bathing suits.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Christophe Gateau/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowed over the Greek island of Rhodes, Greece, on Saturday, as emergency personnel evacuated hundreds of people from wildfires spreading toward coastal villages.

item.title: Huge Protest March Reaches Jerusalem After 5-Day Trek From Tel Aviv
item.description: Tens of thousands of protesters reached Jerusalem on Saturday, some having walked 40 miles from Tel Aviv. The march highlighted the depth of opposition to a government plan to restrain the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israelis marching toward Jerusalem on Saturday in protest of plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the judicial system.

item.title: Far Right May Rise as Kingmaker in Spanish Election
item.description: A messier political landscape has lent leverage to the extremes, leaving a hard-right party with a chance to share power for the first time since Franco.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters hanging this past week in a crowded neighborhood of Barcelona, ahead of the general elections.

item.title: 11 Killed in Suspected Arson in San Luis Río Colorado
item.description: Prosecutors say a man hurled a firebomb at the bar after being ejected. Mexico has struggled to tamp down on raging violent crime.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Zelensky and Erdogan Discuss Collapsed Ukraine Grain Deal
item.description: The Ukrainian leader said he had spoken with the NATO chief and the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine since the full-scale invasion began last February.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a Ukrainian assault unit taking cover from drones and shelling at a frontline position in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Challenged by Tech and Market Forces, Independent Bookshops Bounce Back
item.description: Their demise was long predicted and pandemic closings were a heavy blow, but many local shops are thriving again.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Mosaic Books in Kelowna, British Columbia, is among Canada’s thriving independent shops.

item.title: Malaysia Halts Festival After Kiss Between The 1975 Members
item.description: The episode comes as rights groups have warned of growing intolerance against lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in the country, where homosexuality is a crime.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the band The 1975 performing in Brazil in March. The band’s frontman kissed another male band member at a recent performance in Malaysia.

item.title: A Story of Arab Loss Comes to Life at a Kibbutz in Israel
item.description: A museum founded by pioneering Zionists has been hosting a sweeping retrospective of Palestinian art.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition of artworks by the Abu Shakra family has brought record crowds to the art museum at the Ein Harod kibbutz.

item.title: How Venezuela’s Oil Industry has Devastated the Environment
item.description: Gas flares and leaking pipelines from Venezuela’s once-booming oil industry, hobbled by U.S. sanctions and mismanagement, are polluting towns and a major lake.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera, Sheyla Urdaneta and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neighbors playing board games under a sky lit by gas flares.

item.title: Japan Is Trying to Use Ammonia to Make Coal Cleaner
item.description: Japan says that by blending ammonia with coal in its boilers, it can make coal less damaging to the planet. But the technology faces many hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piles of coal stored at Jera’s thermal power station in Hekinan, Japan.

item.title: In Belarus, the Protests Were Three Years Ago. The Crackdown Is Never-Ending.
item.description: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko brutally repressed those who opposed his claim of re-election as president. The crackdown on dissent has only deepened since.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Batters Ukraine’s Ability to Export Grain in Black Sea Confrontation
item.description: Russia held exercises demonstrating its power to sink ships and stop those that try to run its blockade. For Ukrainian food exports to resume, Moscow said, a list of demands must be met.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Farnaz Fassihi, Victoria Kim and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: A storage building near Odesa that was heavily damaged by a Russian attack. Missile strikes destroyed 100 tons of peas and 20 tons of barley in Odesa.

item.title: William Majcher, Retired R.C.M.P. Officer, Charged With Spying for China
item.description: The officer was also charged under Canada’s Security of Information Act with helping Beijing “identify and intimidate’’ an individual.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A police officer outside the Canadian embassy in Beijing in May, after China expelled a Canadian diplomat in retaliation for Canada’s expulsion of a Chinese diplomat.

item.title: Russia Raises Interest Rates, Trying to Cool Wartime Economy
item.description: With the ruble weakening and the government spending ever more money on the war in Ukraine, Moscow took unexpectedly sharp action to curb inflation.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A currency exchange office in St. Petersburg this month. The ruble fell against the U.S. dollar following the Wagner Group rebellion in June.

item.title: Four Charged in Gold Coin Theft From German Museum
item.description: The arrests came about eight months after thieves cut fiber optic cables, broke into a museum in Bavaria and stole 483 ancient gold coins, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Police officers search for evidence related to the theft of gold coins on a private property in Plate, Germany.

item.title: Russia Ending Ukraine Grain Deal Could Upend Food Security in Africa
item.description: Somalia, Ethiopia and others in the Horn of Africa could be hit the hardest, a leader of an aid group said.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: A worker preparing baked goods with wheat from Ukraine at a bakery in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Sunday.

item.title: How to Fight Canada’s Wildfires in the Era of Climate Change
item.description: Canada’s record-breaking wildfire season shows the need to shift from suppressing fires to preventing them as fires become more difficult to combat.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A fire in British Columbia this week. With months left in the wildfire season more than 27 million acres of forest have burned, five times the annual average.

item.title: 4 Takeaways From Britain’s By-Elections
item.description: Among the takeaways from the vote, which saw two losses for Conservatives but also one win, was that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is down but not out.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Mr. Sunak with Steve Tuckwell, the newly elected conservative member of Parliament, on Friday in Ruislip, England.

item.title: Only Early Birds Will See Acropolis as Workers Strike Over Heat
item.description: Security guards and others say the extreme temperatures in Athens and at other historical sites are dangerous for them and for tourists. The employees are stopping work at noon at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Tourists at the Acropolis in Athens on Thursday.

item.title: Amsterdam to Bar Cruise Ships From Central Terminal
item.description: The Dutch capital will stop cruise ships from docking in the city center as part of a campaign to curb pollution and reduce the flow of tourists.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A cruise ship at the passenger terminal in central Amsterdam last year.

item.title: What to Read to Understand the Unrest in France
item.description: Severe protests have roiled France in recent weeks, after a police officer fatally shot a French teenager of Algerian and Moroccan descent in a suburb of Paris. The demonstrations fit a longstanding pattern.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters at a memorial march for Nahel Merzouk, who was killed by a police officer last month in Nanterre, France.

item.title: India Reels From Shortage of Tomatoes, a Culinary Staple
item.description: “We have stopped eating tomatoes in salad,” one shopper said, “and we are not making any tomato-based vegetable dishes.”
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Buying tomatoes at a vegetable market this month in Hyderabad, India.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Plan Crisis Grows as Air Reservists Threaten to Stop Serving
item.description: In a move that experts say could hurt Israel’s military readiness, pilots and other personnel issued a warning after Benjamin Netanyahu pressed ahead with a plan to limit judicial power.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli mounted riot police confront demonstrators gathering along a highway in Tel Aviv on Thursday during a protest against the government’s judicial overhaul bill.

item.title: Russia Detains Igor Girkin, a Critic of Putin’s War Effort in Ukraine: What to Know
item.description: The arrest was a sign that Russia was clamping down further on dissent, even among prominent nationalists, after last month’s brief mutiny by Wagner mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Igor Girkin, also known as Strelkov, in Moscow in 2022.

item.title: Why Is Switzerland — of All Places — Importing So Much Cheese?
item.description: The cheese-proud country has recently imported more of the stuff than it exports, a worry for farmers and traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Gruyère cheese at a production facility in Bulle, Switzerland. The country has recently been importing more cheese than it exports.

item.title: Around the Globe, Searing Heat With No Sign of Relief
item.description: In Asia, Europe and the United States, records are shattering, and forecasters say there’s no respite in sight.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Mullany, Delger Erdenesanaa and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Socrates Baltagiannis/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Red Cross handing out water near the Acropolis in Athens on Friday.

item.title: Spain’s Election Puts Focus on Leading Parties’ Allies
item.description: Before voting Sunday, a focus on the leading parties’ allies has dominated the campaign — and obscured debate about more fundamental issues.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Polls suggest that Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, Spain’s Socialist leader, may be ousted by conservatives on Sunday.
